p: A warmer climate is predicted to have pronounced impacts on local fauna and flora [ 1, 2], especially in northern latitudes [ 3]. The breeding performance of many birds is likely to be adversely affected [ 4– 7]. More than a decade ago, Visser et al. [ 8] predicted that warmer springs should lead to earlier mating and a temporal mismatch with the optimal hatching time for the offspring. In a later study of the breeding phenology of an insectivorous passerine, the great tit ( Parus major), they showed that the optimal synchrony between hatching time and irruption of caterpillar food supply was distorted in years with earlier and warmer springs [ 9]. Later studies have largely confirmed this ‘mismatch’ hypothesis both for non-migratory [ 10] and migratory birds [ 11].
